Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, the spreadsheet for our project open on one side, the telemarketing call list on the other. As a colleague, I knew I had to finish my part of the report by noon—if I didn’t, the next person couldn’t start, and the whole team’s timeline would unravel. But as a telemarketer, today was the last day of the quarter, and we were just shy of our sales target. Management had made it clear: if we didn’t hit the number, there’d be no bonuses, and worse, we’d all face a penalty. My phone buzzed with reminders from my sales manager, while my teammate pinged me, asking if I’d be done soon. My stomach twisted. Every minute I spent on calls was a minute lost on the report, but if I ignored the calls, I’d let my sales team down. I could feel the pressure mounting from both sides, each demanding my full attention, each with consequences I couldn’t ignore.
